I so badly wanted the Scorpio edition. But like major Nelson said once  they are gone they‚Äôre gone‚Ä¶ But that wasn‚Äôt the case... I initially pre-ordered the regular Xbox one x but on day of the the release the Scorpio edition was back in stock to magically. I promptly returned my standard eddition and re-ordered the Scorpio edition. I know it‚Äôs the same thing but I‚Äôve been a big fan of the Xbox for years and followed the release of the new system from when they originally announced at  E3 the year before. In addition to the special finish it also comes with a free vertical stand  that I would‚Äôve bought for $20-$30 anyway.  The side has a nice gradient finish that goes from black to gray with a Scorpion like texture to accompany the change in color. The controller and console both have project scorpio written on it in bright Xbox green. Came with a free Xbox live trail and a a trial for the new Xbox game pass which is awesome 100+ games plus new exclusives instantly! Now the actual system! Oh boy is it quick! Load times are crazy fast compared to the OG xb1. 1tb was less than I‚Äôd hoped but what I expected. Wished it had of been a solid state drive like the elite I have but most my games are on externals anyway which are faster. I love that they give you the option for 4K or a performance mode that ups the frame rate. Which is clutch because I thinks frames are king 60fps>4K anyday. Which makes it a great option for ppl who don‚Äôt own a 4K tv just yet. So this system has room to grow as 4K TVs become cheaper. Also offers active sync that smooshes jitter for a buttery smooth playback. HDR is also included as is Dolby Atmos. Which are both hidden gems. Atmos Sound and hdr color will make you look at games in a new way. Like how did I do without this all my life!?!? Makes games super cinematic. All and all I am very happy with my purchase and can‚Äôt wait to see what video game developers will do with this beast of a machine. Now we wait and enjoy!

I'm not going to describe it because many people already did it, but let me tell you some extra information:* If you want to use Xbox360 games review the list at Xbox website, not all of them are enabled.  For the ones that work (like Call of Duty Advanced Warfare) they run perfect, no issues at all.* Yes, it's 110v-240v (autoswitch).  You don't need a transformer for 220v (in fact I'm using it in this way)* It brings 1 wireless controller only (I had to return it to Microsoft because it had random disconnections). You have to raise a case through Xbox support (you have to logon with your MS account, the same one you use in the Xbox)* Check the warranty date at Xbox website (it's 1 year manufacturer's warranty). I had to claim for it because it appeared as I had only 6 months of warranty.* Warranty for accesories (like controllers) is 90 days* Don't forget to register your Xbox, you cannot raise any tickets if it's not registeredHope you find this information useful

Xbox One X is truly powerful and heavy too. Don't lift it with one hand you might hurt your wrist its amazing how Microsoft manage to put all that component inside such a small body. The Xbox One X UI is finally fast and fluent before with the Xbox One and Xbox One S UI was so sluggish and sometimes unresponsive now everything loads up quick like the thumbnails from Xbox Store all data reads faster now including steaming, uploading and downloading (Even in 4K). The Xbox One X makes your classic Original Xbox and Xbox 360 games look better then ever the textures are more crisp anti-aliasing is great no more edgy lines. Not every game is 4K, but it has more support from developers to put native 4K/HDR with 30 FPS and 1080p/HDR with 60 FPS then PS4 Pro. When it comes to third party games Xbox One X is the way to go.Xbox One X is a must buy, but the bad news is there is no exclusives for Xbox One X so if you own a high end gaming PC with a GTX 1080 your wasting money on something that has the same games you can play on PC technically you are not missing anything. When it comes to consoles I suggest PS4 Pro and Switch, plus a high end gaming PC with this you are not missing anything. Xbox One X is target for people that have no time and money to build a gaming PC like me PC gaming is super expensive...>_<Overall Xbox One X is the best alternative for a gaming PC its powerful, fast and cheap....o(^-^)o

Really makes a difference on Forza Motorsport 7 and Forza Horizon 3. If you plan to install more than a couple of 4K games, get an external USB 3.0/3.1 drive. 4K games take up a lot of space. A good external drive will load just as fast or faster than the internal. It would almost make sense for Microsoft to sell these with a smaller drive installed, but smaller than 1TB isn't cheaper anyway. I also have a second external drive attached to save game clips. You can record a clip up to one hour long clips with an external drive. It requires separate drives for each purpose, storage and media. For storage, let the XBox One format it. For media, format it as NTFS using a PC. Once a game is installed on the external drive, it can be played on any other XBox One. All video formats will be available, whatever the machine supports. It makes a decent heater for a small room also.

Awesome console for high quality home theaters, but with huge updates to download.  I have all the consoles, used to be a PC game, and actually already owned a XBOX ONE.  I purchased this as an entry into 4k.  My primary gaming setup is a basement home theater a 1080 projector, 4k projectors are still way to expensive, but I was willing to buy a 4k TV for the living room.  I purchased the XB1X console in conjunction with a 65 inch Sony 4k HDR capable television.  This console is also plugged into a high quality receiver and speaker system.  I have 6 games that are enhanced for the console and they are really amazing in action.  You can't appreciate the improvement until you see it live in 4k with HDR, any online video in 1080 is not going to do it justice..  Forza 7 and Rise of the Tomb Raider are stand outs.  There is a very big difference between streaming 4k signals via netflix or youtube and a native 4k game or 4k blu ray disc.  Until this console was available I did not see a good reason to take the plunge.  If you want a next level experience and have the cash to burn it is a fun ride once the games are installed.This console exists side by side with the XB1 which is designed to run games in regular HD, so whenever you install a new game it has to download all the improved 4k textures and assets from the internet.  This can be significant, for example in the case of Forza 7, the update was 62GB.  Gone are the days when you can insert a game and just play, every one of the enhanced games I have played required a pretty significant update.  My internet speed is 100Mbs, some of these updates basically needed most of the a night to download.  The downloads will continue when your console is on stand by, so you pop the game in, get the download going and walk away.  You can't just pop a disc in and play.  This may not always be the case, it is possible future releases could include the 4k assets on disc, but for now it is the reality.I am curious to see how this console evolves in the future.  During the run up to release a lot was made of its VR capabilities, but MS has gone silent on that.  I don't know if there is a pending announcement, but it is something I will like to try out, so hopefully it comes back.  There is also an opportunity to push this console beyond what could be supported by the regular XB1 console, so I am not sure how that will play out.  Will there be a new XB console released when the Playstation 5 comes out?  There are certainly some open questions regarding the future.  In the meantime if you want the best experience outside of a custom PC gaming rig, the XB1X is the best available option right now.  If you have a great display and sound system, you finally have a simple device that can pump native 4k content through your system.

When AXX RyzXX not rise, IntXX CPU performance like gently squeezing out toothpaste, then note 7 boom, PC DIY cost more pay than 2015 year.If you want to play 2160p games and do not cost much, Xbox One X is the only choice.Open the box, the first layer is paper pocket, with fast installation guide,one month game pass exchange code and 14 day live gold exchange code. The box is designed on the left and right sides, and the left white paper box is manual, power cord, HDMI line and handle (including dry battery). The right side is the console of the package of the EPE film.The console is asymmetric design. The design concept can feel hard core more than Xbox One S, not so showy and fashionable. Low key color, dot embossed texture with irregular geometry made Xbox One X itself.This HDMI2.0b play 4K 10bit 4:2:0 HDR 60Hz signal.1t HDD only last 780.9GiB to user.Xbox One X Enhanced games usually cost 40~110GiB,also their loarding time cost more than 30s.I hope MS offer $650 for 512GB SSD One X model.someone po (PC)SM951 (2150MB/s seq R, 1250MB/s Seq W) opens the call of duty 11, and loads up to 10 seconds. Battlefield 4 loading time is 16 seconds (HDD raid 0 is 1 minutes, plextXX M6S is 22 seconds).I have been away from high performance PC for 5 more years, so now, a lot games are waiting for me.

Figured it was time for an upgrade considering my first gen xbox one(day one) was starting to really run games slower than ever, disc drive was not wanting to give games back, etc. Worth the money. My buddies and I have been on xbox live for 8+ years, this is by far the best xbox system I've used, runs fast, displays beautifully on a 4k tv.If you're looking to buy an xbox or playstaton for the first time, take it from someone who has been using both the last 10+ years(90% of that time on an xbox, though I've owned all gens of playstation), go with the playstation for game options/exclusives alone. PSN has given me really cool classic titles for free, and has many cheap for purchase(old final fantasy games, jak and daxter games, etc.). Xbox Live has given me Killer instinct, among other incredibly forgettable games. Would you rather play a new Halo, or Bloodborne 2? Sea of Theives, or The Last Of Us 2? Exactly.If you're like me and already have way too much invested into xbox live, all your friends play xbox live, all your games are on there, whatever it is, then this is truly a beast of a game console and the smoothest running xbox, or game console to date.Pros:Truly looks great with a 4k setup.Much slimmer/sleeker than the original design.Physical power button, not touch.USB port is front facing this time.More storage if you dont have an external hard drive.Backwards compatibility is awesome. Cool I can still play Half Life 2.Destroys games, the witcher 3 and battlefield 1 run smoother/look better than ever.Cons:The price. I mean, you could buy a lot of snacks and beer with $500.Xbox Live instead of Playstation Network, if you've used both, PSN is a better service, Sony gets much better exclusives/indies imo.Overall:5 stars because it's not the console's fault that I'm salty about my friends and I not deciding to get ps3's instead of 360's back in late 2006.The Xbox One X is undoubtedly the most capable, powerful gaming console on the market, and it proves this with it's game performance.

What a beautiful console. I have ran tests in a few games. From backward compatible games to recent released games to some pretty ages games. All on the enhancement settings not in 4K setting but it won‚Äôt make a difference to be honest. For a game like The division this game is a beauty. On the Xbox one X  I have done load time tests and saw that the loading times have increased 2-3 times faster then the original Xbox one from 2013. From being 26-30 seconds on the original between each and every load to 12-19 seconds on the Xbox one X which varies depending what you are doing ( in the main menu when entering into the game is the longest times while fast traveling is the shorter times ). This also speaks for a game like mass effect andromeda which if you original Xbox one player should ever played the load times on the main menu to the doors when your traveling around takes forever to open or load up but with the Xbox one x the load times are such a significant increase in load times. When walking around the ship in mass effect andromeda the doors usually open before you even step near it orrrr it will open instantly when next to the door which in the original Xbox one it was so tedious to wait for those freakin doors to load up and open so you can enter the next room. And when your game loads up on the main menu ? I would say it‚Äôs close to being cut in half. In games like borderlands 2 and the pre sequel I never tested it on the original Xbox one but I‚Äôve entered the game through the main menu and it took literally about 6-7 seconds. Fast traveling for some reason was 9-10 but that is deff fast ! In CPU heavy Games or even just very tough performing Games the Xbox one X dominates the market by cutting the load times by almost half of not half compared to the PlayStation pro which is quite insane. And that‚Äôs after the patch the Bethesda brought to the console. Before it was even faster. Over all in all my games I have seen significant improvements whether it‚Äôs framerate or even load times and in game quality. And that‚Äôs with the including 1 TB hard drive ? Amazing. On the new game pubg this thing is a beauty. Now it‚Äôs does almost locked 30fps in 4K which for pubg is completely unbelievable for a 500$ piece of technology. No crashes, little rubber banding in the beginning of games everybody now and then and such smooth gameplay compared to the original Xbox one and even the one S. All games will be improved in such significant ways compared to the one S and the original Xbox one. I have 13 games installed right now. Borderlands the pre sequel, call of duty black ops 3, call of duty infinite warfare, fallout 3, fallout 4 ( including the far harbor and nuka world dlc downloaded ), forza Motorsport 7 demo, halo 5, L.A noire, mass effect andromeda, pubg, record definitive edition, skate 3 and, Tom Clancy‚Äôs the division and have 315.3 GB of storage left. And this is with all the patches installed for the 4K/enhancements. The only downside in my opinion would be the fact that when setting up the console for something reason it takes about 280 GB away for idk what reason so you actually start off with 720 GB or so I believe I started with 718 to Ben exact. But honestly it‚Äôs worth 500$. No and I mean no other piece of gaming and video streaming tech can compare to a console like this. The enhancements and improvements with this compared to the PlayStation 4 pro is literally night and day. And a 500$ pc cannot compare this thing blows it out of the water. I haven‚Äôt also experience any issues at all it‚Äôs the best experience. Also you will be saving a lot of space cause this thing is literally small as hell ! The thing that‚Äôs blew me away also is the fact that this thing isn‚Äôt such a powerful console with some top notch tech yet it‚Äôs almost soundless. It‚Äôs really quite ! It‚Äôs deff worth it for 500$. I really hope everyone could get this to experience true top notch gaming and fun.

Microsoft‚Äôs New console is a beast! With a very powerful and well thought out console. I had the first generation Xbox one and that thing is louder runs hotter and now a papper weight, after getting the X. I run a Samsung 50‚Äù UHD TV with a Highspeed HDMI(comes in box) and a Sat6(10GBS) hardwire to my router with a bypassed and portforwarded though the fire wall. The X I believe has a Sat4,5 so with 10GBs a sexy WiFi (ATT U-verse fiber optic) I am hitting a slow dowload of 350MBS with a High of 600MB/s (Open bandwidth) Now This may varey apon internet provider and what they offer, but I wanted to put it my review to show the upgrade of the last gen witch for me only hit a of 150mbs. So in all my x does 1GB every 2 seconds and a 48GB game in 96 seconds or 1min 36sec.Now for the UHD output 4K is made in difrent ways 1080 in a cross grid then upscaled and 4K output. The Xbox does the 4K UHD output(True 4K) With my tv Running 10 Bit 32collor pallet. So that‚Äôs 32 colors put into a single pixel and 4K is 4096x2160 next to a HD (1080) 1920x1080. The console puts out 283,115,520 colors 60times a second. Your brain can see at around 25 FPS(Frames per sec) and drops below look like screen tears and slow mo. Now The one is a True gamers dream console and would only be available with a mid level gameing PC with a $700 price tag. Now the XBOX has a $509 MSRP After taxes.(Texas order). So it is the best bang for the buck! It does have a solid state drive a WD 1TB(1000GB) witch could have been swaped for a SSD during production for faster download speed hence the high of a 300mbS with a sat 5 capable of 7GBS a sec. Wich isn‚Äôt bad at all but I am nit picky and my only gripe.But In all a stock a Gameing rig you pay $500 for and well worth $200 more.  Not only loads faster a Higher 16GB ram for visible data and I game meshes to not have to load the worlds as much. A plug in and play with internal power brick a multi media player SD, Blue Ray, and UHD4k DVD. And enginuity that blows Sony out of the water like Hiroshima, and grafics that suck you in and makes the game seem feel and look amazing!

First let me say I love the Xbox one x, I have been an Xbox fan from the beginning. I ordered the Xbox one x because I wanted to upgrade to 4k. I purchased a new Yamaha 4k Receiver and 82" 4k TV. I received my Xbox and everything went smooth and loved the picture and gaming. Here is why I am only rating it 3 stars. Does Microsoft think people are going to spend thousands of dollars on 4k equipment only to play games? I just upgraded my DirecTV to 4k and the designers of the Xbox one x had no concept of anyone needing 4k pass through. After reading reviews about problems and glitches, I was all but ready to pass on this system. However, I did my homework and really wanted the chance to experience it myself.  I purchased the Sony 65" 930E TV and the Yamaha A770 receiver. The only thing missing was the Xbox One X. I played for a week on my Xbox One and was really enjoying the crisp, bright graphics, saving my eye-sight. Then I made the decision and added the Xbox One X. Wow, it does make a worthy difference. The same games I was playing before look perfect. Forza Horizon 3 and Wolfenstein II don't have any upgraded 4k patches, to my knowledge. However they look so much better and run so smoothly. I have not experienced any glitches either. Turn in 4k HDR, in your TV's HDMI settings, then turn on 4k on the Xbox One X.Easy as that, looks great, runs great, and the cooling has been whisper quiet. Money well spent.

Not a significantly noticeable difference in speed. When I turned it on expected apps and games to load much faster. But it's only a few seconds.There's also a new brief startup animation  before the standard Xbox screen pops up and it happens every time you start up the system.The upscaling is great, but most games don't have enough of a graphical benefit to justify the purchase.Most games have the same locked framerate and even though you load in games faster most people don't have the X so you still have to wait for others to join in anyway.Not really worth it if you have the original or the S.Most multi-player games also restrict a lot of the benefits of the X in order to maintain a even level of competition.You also have to re download every game you have and sign in to every app.
missing a cable

Had so many issues from the start. Would not always sign you in or would not connect to Xbox live.  My original Xbox One worked fine.  This one was hooked directly to router.  Spoke with Microsoft techs and performed all their steps to no avail.  Very disappointing.  Getting new one sent out.  Hopefully next one will be better.=====================================================UPDATE.......Replacement Xbox One X arrived and exact same issues.  Finally found a way to fix it "sort of".  Turn the auto-sign in option off.  Including the controller sign in option.  While you have to click the Xbox button and sign in each time it does not give any issues.  As stated earlier I had non-stop issues with it not signing in my account or Xbox live even though I had internet connected.  Since I disabled that I have had no further issues.  If you do another thing to do as well is when you shut it off go to your settings and select the option to completely shut down.  I have not had to do that but its an option if you have more issues than me.  I hope Microsoft fixes this glitch soon, with the cost of this system it is rather frustrating.  One other thing, this may have been a fluke but wanted to mention just in case.  During a game I did get disconnect from my account mid-game.  Only happened once and signed back in right away but just wanted to put that out there for everyone.  Be sure to vote helpful if this helped you.  I'll keep updating if anything else comes up.

Let me start off by saying that I am an Xbox fanboy but man do I have a love/hate relationship with Microsoft.The good: When paired with a 4K tv, this gem delivers!!!! When playing Xbox one X enchanced games on this beast, it will set the standard for your taste in graphics moving forward. Example, Gears of war 4 on this was literally jaw dropping! I played through the game not even giving a damn about the story. The game world alone was just so rich, vibrant, and finely detailed on this console!The bad: We all know Microsoft has an exclusive problem but coming from a PS4....it‚Äôs night and day how HUGE this problem is. There are literally a handful of GOOD games that really take advantage of this consoles graphics and once you have played all of them, you are just sitting there like....‚Äùso ahhhh....when‚Äôs the next ‚Äòexclusive‚Äô coming out.‚ÄùBrutally honest: This console is a gem when played with games that are made specifically for it, like the new Forza, but once you‚Äôve played them all your left wondering whether you should have waited until after E3 2018 to see if they will fix their exclusive problem or not.My advice...kills me to say it...PS4 pro will give you more bang for your buck. Unless you have money laying around, wait until after E3 2018 to see if this console is really worth it. Now if you have never had an Xbox one then yea..obviously get the best version possible to ride out this console generation but if you already have one and thinking about upgrading...wait until the price goes down and more enchanced games come out mate.

I've been an Xbox fan since 2002 and I am proud to own an Xbox One X. I bought the original Xbox One at launch and I was stoked when they announced the X! I am currently playing this on my 55" Samsung 1080p tv. I'm saving up to get a Samsung 4k Q7. I've been playing Middle Earth:Shadow of War and it looks amazing with the Quality option activated. It takes the 4k resolution and turns it into a 1080p resolution with better textures and greater draw distances. I was surprised and very impressed with how much of a difference it made from playing it on my original Xbox One to playing it on the Xbox One X! There is also an option to have a better resolution in Shadow of war,I played around with the 2 settings and the Quality option was ultimately the better of the 2. I also played Wolfenstien 2 with the Xbox One X enhancement on and it was pretty awesome,especially the cutsceens! I can't wait to see what games look like on my Samsung 4k TV when I get it! I never finished Fallout 4,but I definitely will when I get my 4k tv! Games load a lot faster on the Xbox One X,it's very impressive and I am glad I decided to get one even though I don't have a 4k tv. The Xbox One X is definitely worth the $500 considering that's how much the original Xbox One was at launch in 2013!

As an owner of a PC with SLI GTX 1080 Ti, I have no difficulty in saying this Xbox hands down provides the best living room experience. Nothing comes close. 4K streaming, 4K Blu Ray, 4K high end PC quality gaming in the living room.The only complaint I see people have is with the price tag. Honestly, I find that ridiculous as $500 is a steal for how powerful this box is. You'd need a PC where the graphics card alone is $400-$500 to run games like the Xbox One X does. You absolutely get more than you pay for out of this console if you care at all about the visual fidelity of your living room games.To summarize, I have nothing but positive things to say about the new Xbox. The build quality is superb, the box is whisper silent, and the box is rock solid stable. Xbox 360 and Xbox OG backwards compatibility. All Xbox One games(including non enhanced ones) run noticeably better on this- they don't drop frames where the old Xbox would and games with a variable resolution stay locked at the highest resolution. 4 free games per month that you get to keep forever simply by having Xbox Live. Get yourself a huge external hard drive and you're good to go.

I've been an Xbox junkie since the original Halo was released in 2001. Since that time I've never owned another console--unless you count the Switch, but that's my daughters. Nonetheless, this thing is beast! It's like an Xbox had sex with a computer and this is their offspring. Don't listen to those ninny PlayStation fanboys touting how much better the PlayStation is--the Xbox One X blows that pile of hot garbage out of the water (toilet water). For those that nitpick every single negative thing, let me be very clear...EVERY console has something wrong with it. In fact, everything has something wrong with it if you look hard enough. I could probably find something wrong with the fork that I'm going to be using later tonight to eat my dinner. My advice to you--stop complaining and just enjoy it!In all seriousness, I was extremely skeptical before purchasing this. I honestly didn't think there would be a major improvement with the games--visually speaking. I mostly wanted to get the One X for it's smaller form factor, built in power supply, and rear venting. To my surprise, I immediately noticed the graphical improvement with the One X enhanced games. I'm not exactly sure how to explain it other than to say it just looks amazing. The detail is crystal clear, the colors are more vibrant, and overall, it just runs more smoothly.Buy this, you won't regret it. If you do, you're lame.

This console upgrade is really great. So far the only games I've played on it have been really good in visual quality & I say that while only currently having a 1080p TV. Why did I get it then? Because I like Xbox & I wanted the most powerful console on the market. You don't NEED 4K gaming to enjoy a game. Just give me 1080p & 60FPS & I'm happy. I have a PS4 & I love Nintendo too, so I'm not one of these Xbox fanboys, I just have preferences.Now, if YOU don't need the most capable console of this generation, Microsoft has made the Xbox One S, which costs less & does everything this console does, but it doesn't play 4K Blu-Rays or output games to 4K. Sony also made the PS4 & Nintendo has the Switch. You have your choices.So, this console is great. The only thing I can't figure out is why Microsoft doesn't include an easy way to stream to either Twitch, or YouTube. Sony put those into the PS4, so Microsoft could do it too. Anyways, most of the people who've put bad reviews of this console either had it fail on them, they're most likely trolls, or they're dumb. For those, I say either request a refund or replacement if it fails on you, don't whine in the review section of the console's page on this site, if you're a troll, stop because you're obvious & annoying, & if you're dumb, stop being dumb & do some research on Google or something before you whine about things that are easily fixable if you did. This console has great graphical capabilities, a good amount of storage (though I'd still suggest getting an external hard drive like I did for storing games you want installed, but aren't currently playing), & a great host of features. This is the most capable console right now & it's more powerful than all the others on the market right now & it's great if you're a more hardcore gamer. It makes games look better than even the PS4 Pro & is meant to be enjoyed, so have your fun.And to the people that'll say Microsoft doesn't have any exclusives, or just get a gaming PC, Microsoft has a lot of exclusives coming, if you even bothered checking, & either let people enjoy console gaming, since it's still a thing, or go enjoy your PC because the console manufacturers will keep making them until the market dies out, so it's a moot point.

My four year old Xbox one finally gave out on me which gave me a reason to buy the X. I hooked it up to my 4K tv and now gaming monitor has no purpose, there‚Äôs no going back to 1080p after playing forza in 4K. Although the performance has increased and the 4K is awesome I wouldn‚Äôt spend the money if my old Xbox one was still working.

The extra horse power is easily apparent from the get go, from the Dashboard and guide being super quick and slick, to the 4k HDR options or on certain titles that can't reach 60fps you have 1080p 60fps ultra settings options and a mix of in between for some games. Games like Gears4, Halo5, AC Origins and Shadow of War are awe inspiring in 4k and 1080p performance mode is a dramatic upgrade on some of these same titles. Hell even games without a patch are running seemlessly and to be honest look alittle better by smoothing over alot of jaggy areas. The console it's self is sexy minimalisum and runs pretty quite. Controller is standard with added texture in the grips. Havent streamed in 4k yet but I have captured and screenshot 4k and it's fast and beautiful.Basically I'm completely happy with buying it, I know 500 seems a bit steep but the console preforms and will no doubt be a part of the next generation will all the power still untapped.

I have yet to get a 4K TV, so I haven't yet seen in person how good games can look on this console, but what I *can* write a review on is the performance of games compared to the regular Xbox One. With some games on the regular Xbox One (especially Fallout 4) there was lots of stuttering and general lagginess. I was always disappointed by that console's specs and performance...but on the One X, those problems disappear. FPS drops and lag are now extremely rare, and games run so much smoother. The load times are also exponentially better--I did some tests, and sometimes load screens in games are cut in half! It's amazing. Very happy with this purchase, and I'm excited to see how it'll look when I get my 4K TV.I also love how there's no giant power brick, it's just a simple power cord, and the power and eject buttons are actual physical buttons...I can't tell you how many times I accidentally pressed the capacitve buttons on the regular XB1. The console is also more sleek and less noisy than the original One, which is saying something considering it has more advanced hardware!

I was an early adopter of the Xbox One original. I liked all the functionalities that it offered, but honestly i had a lot of problems with it. It was slow, loading my tv guide took forever... to the point i thought it froze. it would lose connection to the internet randomly. And admittedly, maybe it was just mine. So the Xbox one S came out and i passed it up, as i figured eh, still not really the console i wanted. In comes the One X.40% more power, full 4K. Its fast, games look amazing, channel guide actually loads fast, this is the Xbox One that should have come from the start. I like this console so much it convinced me to purchase a 4K TV to go along with it. I watched some Amazon 4K streaming, played Forza, and Assassins Creed. Not a single hiccup during these play times, this machine handled it like a champ. It also now has the power supply built into it, so no more power brick. Just a simple removable cable running from the Xbox to your wall.I am taking 1 star off because of two small problems i have had with it so far. I was having trouble getting my controller(s) to start and connect to the console randomly one morning. Held them right in front of it, walked around the room... nothing. Simply did a hard reset, and everything was back to normal. Similarly, Wifi constantly kept dropping one time... i'd connect and it would drop within 5 minutes. Only thing that solved that was a hard reset again. I've only had the system for about 5 days, so i was a little surprised already to be having issues.Besides those easy fixes, the console is a beast, and i love it. If you have any questions please feel free to drop a comment and i will get back to you !

There is no learning curve exspecially it you've used an Xbox One. Setup will take a few mainly due to an system update. After that if you have 4K TV you'll want to check your settings to make sure 4K output is selected. Also, if upgrading from Xbox One / Xbox One S, using an exturnal hard drive will speed up and reduced bandwidth usage of having to download games and apps again. You can also use Network Transfer and copy games from your other Xbox.Performance is unmatched by any other console available today and for the next few years. You will notice reduced load times for all your games you own currently. (I can't say this will always be the case as game devs truly take full advantage to this power house).Games look amazing and yes even games that haven't been patched yet for the X. As a multi-platform game enthusiast I can say I am really impressed with the visual fidelity that this new machine provides. I'm using it in conjunction with a Sony Bravia 43 inch 4K HDR TV and the visuals this device delivers are fantastic. For reference I also own and PS4 pro and have a dedicated gaming PC with a core i7 and a GTX 1080 that I've compared it against. Obviously the PC will outperform it but at nearly 3 times the cost. You can't build a PC that would get this performance for 499. The only downside is that you are dependent on developers doing the work to make the enhancements to their games, but I will say that anything with a dynamic resolution will still look sharper on this device. Gears of War 4 and Forza 7 are night and day compared to the standard Xbox one on my screen. Even the enhanced 360 games like Gears of War 3 look really nice up-scaled to 1080p. Unless you just don't like Microsoft exclusives, if you have a 4K panel and 499 to spare this should be the console for you.

After owning the original Xbox One from launch, helping a friend set-up an Xbox One S and now buying an Xbox One X, it's unfortunate, but I can safely, new Xbox, same issues! OK let's get this out of the way, I was shocked at how small this system is in person, it was half the size of my UHD Blu-Ray Player and it is built of very high quality, and get this, the power cord is thinner than the HDMI Cable, think Apple TV thin! This system however runs Very Hot, hotter than any other system, including my laptop, and it constantly blows hot air from the rear, so don't even think of putting this anywhere it may block the rear vents, it is however very quiet, with exception to a disc loading data, that is audible, not game breaking but audible. Here is the BIGGEST Issue(s) however, with all this extra power, all this fine workmanship, MS still has not addressed issues plaguing this machine since day one! The menus are still convoluted and horrible to navigate, so much so I swear it has gotten worse than my launch XB1. Installing games, takes FOREVER and worse than that, I can't count how many times I brought game to the front to prompt it to download, I walked away and it went back to "Query" while another started downloading in the background (I was downloading multiple titles and updates). This has been an issue since the day the console launched and MS refuses to acknowledge it, this was a game breaker for me as it was my single biggest complaint from my original unit.I also had strange issues with setting up the audio, it kept telling me it could not find the output, in the end I used bitstream optical, event though I was connected with HDMI, audio sounded great, crisp and clear, but it was kind of an annoyance to not let me select my current set-up, strangely I do not remember this issue with my older unit, may have something to do with the inclusion Atmos in XB1X.Another issue I encountered was with the game "Killer Instinct". This game still has the same HORRIBLE character select screen latency/three second pause in between moving the cursor from one character to the next. This issues was present all the way from day one launch and it is still not fixed, even with the updated horsepower, my PC, which is not as powerful as an XB1X plays this game flawlessly with zero latency, why can't the console that it was created on (and for) do the same?In the end the unit had to go back to Amazon as it had an issue where it was scratching discs upon insertion/exit, ironically my original XB1 had the exact same issue, but once the console was replaced it was fine there after. Follow-up: Since I have received the replacement XBox, I have had a much more pleasurable experience. Everything works, the games install and load as expected, downloads seem to work just fine without issue, and so on. I'm giving this 4 stars instead of 5 because of my initial experience, but overall I'm pleased with the console.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Preamble: I went back and forth between purchasing an Xbox One and a Playstation 4, but decided on the Xbox because of the 4K blu-ray player. Might have been better off just buying a 4K blu-ray player.--Diary--Friday: Xbox arrives on my doorstep in the afternoon. Cool! Unbox the unit, no instructions other than a thin booklet with warnings written in various languages. Go online. A/V setup seems pretty straight forward, plug it in, put batteries in the remote (no instructions on how to link with console), and fire it up. Box starts up and goes into initial setup. Get to screen where initial update takes place, starts to download update package (about 800Mb or so), process stops about 100MB in. Re-boot, get a few more MB on the update download, stops again. Re-boot again, few more MB, at this point I say enough, go out to dinner with my wife (who is wondering why I started this evolution before going to dinner). Get back home, more reboots, finally do a full system reset, some E102 and E105 errors in there, and miraculously by about 1AM everything seem to be set up. Call it a night and go to bed, remembering that I haven't had this much fun since installing OS/2 back in the day, when you had to laboriously feed 36 floppies for the install, only to have it fail at the end and start over...Saturday: Get up, hesitantly push the power on button (will it boot up?) when I am greeted by the Home screen. Hooray! Put in "Planet Earth II" to test out the 4K Blu-ray. Looks gorgeous! Watch a few shows on Amazon and Netflix, looks great, Amazon app a little weird in that you cannot purchase content from it, so had to start up the Amazon app on the TV to rent a movie, then go back to the Xbox app to watch it. Beautiful day!Sunday: Get up, put in another 4K movie (Blade Runner), get a message that it cannot read the disk. Restart the Xbox. Same message. Put in the Planet Earth II disk that worked fine the day before. Can't read the disk. After doing some Internet research, discover that the fix is to do a system reset, preserving games and apps. Remembering the debacle on Friday night, tentatively do so. Box resets, have to go back and set everything back up, put in disk, and now it can load the movie (Blade Runner). Watch first part of the movie, wondering what I've gotten myself into with this Xbox.Monday: Have the day off, so I decide to download Doom III. About 58 GB, takes about 1.5 hours to download. Download halts a couple of times, have to back out and restart, but finally completes. Fire it up, looks great, but after about a minute of game play, get a warning that it cannot save the game. Back out to start screen, game "slot 1" says corrupt file. Do some Internet research, solution seems to be do a system reset, preserving games. Reset game console, set it back up, load Doom, works great, looks awesome. Play for about an hour or so.Tuesday: Forza 6 comes in the mail. Awesome! Put the disk in the console, installation process starts, system tells me that an update will need to be downloaded (about 8 GB) in order to play, say ok, install restarts, where the game console is slowly copying the game files from the disk while simultaneously downloading the update. Process stops after about 1/2 hour. Back out, restart, process starts again. Stops again. Back out again, Xbox won't restart this time, get E105 error. Finally decide that I've had enough, do a full system reset to clear out any saved information, box it back up, notify Amazon to send me a replacement.Maybe I received a defective Xbox and a new one will work better. But even so, the platform seems to me to be somewhat half baked and particularly fault intolerant, where any issue with the seemingly complex chain of events needed to load and play a game is enough to literally make the box unusable and force a system reset, which may or may not be time consuming depending on how much content you have downloaded, but is still certainly an annoyance. So even if there was a hardware malfunction causing the problem, the system does not seem to be all the stable on a good day. Besides which, this is not a console where you can just put in a disk and start playing a game. It seems that you will need a fast broadband connection (and no download limits!) and will still need to allocate an hour or two on the initial setup, even if you own the game on disk. Exciting!Lesson learned: After four days with this console, I liken it to playing Russian Roulette with rubber bullets. If this is the future of game play, then buy a pack of cards. You'll need them anyway to play solitaire while waiting for your games to install.

So I bought the Xbox One X anticipating that it was going to be the deal that moved me into the Xbox/Microsoft world. It arrived a day early and I was off to the races. I bought gold live, an extra controller, and a couple of games to make the switch enjoyable. There were minor issues including lag from home page to other apps, there was always an issues with random drops on connection, and there was always an issues with games randomly closing. I assumed it was either a wifi problem or just my inexperience with Xbox. As the weeks go by the issues increase and soon become a huge annoyance. After about two months, the xbox became unplayable. I could not connect to the internet with either wifi/ethernet. I could not play any games because they were all corrupted. I could hardly move from Home page. Friends lists never loaded. So I did what any person should do when they have no idea what to do, I contacted Xbox support and they ran me through some trouble shooting solutions. After following them to the dot the Xbox became playable again. At least for an hour or two, and then it would go back to its broken state. I went through support about 3-4 times until I just told them I wanted a new one. Luckily for me I was still under warranty because I had only purchased it not too many months ago. So I went through the process and sent it in. The neat part about the process is you can see when it arrives and when it fixed and when its shipped. Well after about a Month I finally got what I believe to be a refurbished Xbox. Ecstatic to have a fixed console I start playing once again. Not more than two weeks go by and I am having a whole new set of hardware issues. The controllers have issues connecting to the Xbox, games seem to freeze and are corrupted. What really through me over the edge though. I had just purchased a new game and I have been waiting months to play Sea of Thieves. I am unable to buy the game through the store on my console, so I head over to my laptop and buy it off the Microsoft site. Soon enough I am downloading the game onto my console so I head into another room and about 25 minutes later I head back to see how far the game has installed and my Xbox is frozen on the "Trouble Shooting Screen." I am unable to do anything so I unplug the console form the power source and wait a couple of minutes. I contact customer support and we hard reset the xbox again. They are now going to send me a brand new Xbox and I am to send my faulty xbox to them. They are charging me a $15 dollar processing fee as well as a $500+ deposit in case I don't send in my Xbox. I will keep you guys updated but hopefully my issues will be fixed and I won't get furthermore screwed.-Feb 10Order has been started but no replacement Xbox has been shipped yet. Current Xbox is malfunctioning and is becoming unplayable.-Feb 20New Xbox has arrives, I will be sending the broken one awaiting my hold to be taken off.-Feb 25

I'd rate the Xbox One X a 4 1/2 star, but since that isn't possible on the Amazon rating system, I'll go ahead and award this console a 5-star.I had no intention of purchasing the Xbox One X because I'm an owner of a PS4 Pro and a high-end gaming PC that's equipped with a GTX 1080 Ti SC2 Hybrid. But my wife wouldn't take no for an answer when I told her that I didn't want anything for my birthday, so I gave in :D.The console is smaller than its predecessors, but it's surprisingly heavy. The design is sleek, which I find far more attractive than the sandwich-design of the PS4 Pro. Compared to Sony's DS4, I much prefer the feel and look of the Xbox One controller, especially in FPS games. However, I still do not understand why Microsoft is so reluctant to include a rechargeable battery pack for the controller or a micro-USB cord (the PS4 comes with both!). I have a handful of micro-USB cords lying around, but they defeat the purpose of the wireless functionality of the controller. I don't want to spend money on freaking AA batteries whenever they run out of juice. And I sure as hell don't want to spend extra on rechargeable battery packs. The Xbox One X is $500! FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS! With that premium price, at least make the controller rechargeable like the DS4.In terms of performance, the X is indeed a monster, but not the kind that Microsoft would like you to believe. Despite their claim that this console can deliver "true 4k," the X utilizes the same checkerboard technology of the PS4 Pro, albeit with a higher resolution. If you are still uncertain, you can look up videos by Digital Foundry, who delves into great technical detail regarding the performance of the Xbox One X. The console's 6 teraflop video card is very powerful for a gaming device of its kind, but it pales in comparison to what's currently available in the GPU market. Games that were released in the last three years will look incredible and perform well on the X due to the higher horsepower. But AAA titles are becoming more hardware demanding every year, so it'll be interesting to see how the Xbox One X carry itself in the next 2-4 years, assuming the console cycle will last that long. In the meantime, however, all multi-platform games will undoubtedly look better on the X than they will on the PS4 Pro.But sadly, Microsoft's library of exclusive games is anemic. While Sony continues to push out enticing previews of upcoming exclusive games, Microsoft backpedals to the games of the past. The list is quite vast, but most of the Xbox 360 games that I own and want to play have yet to be made backwards compatible, which renders the functionality completely pointless at this time. As a long time ardent fan of the Halo series, I would love to play Halo: Reach with an Xbox One X enhanced visuals, HDR, and 60fps. But given 343 Industries' peculiar reluctance to support the fan favorite Halo game, I highly doubt that Reach will ever receive the upgrade that it deserves. So please, Microsoft and 343, do yourselves and the fans a favor: give Halo: Reach, one the best Xbox 360 exclusive titles, an Xbox One X Enhancement!Regardless of Microsoft's misleading claims, the X packs quite a bit for $500. Unlike the PS4 Pro, the Xbox One X is equipped with a 4k HDR Blu-ray player, which alone retails for $200. Thus, the console is a very well rounded home device, and it also gives me a reason to start collecting movie DVDs again. And in 4K HDR! Combine all this with my new LG 43UJ63 that I purchased recently, my setup is practically complete!My final criticism regarding the X is its limited storage capacity. 1TB may seem large, but it will fill up extremely fast due to the 4K assets of enhanced games.

Update 3-10-18A very interesting feature I found for the Xbox One X is that at a system level, games that have 4K assets or resolutions higher than 1080p would be super-scaled to fit regular full-HD screens. What this means is, even those who don‚Äôt have a 4K TV can benefit from sharper image quality. Be it the likes of Shadow of War and Rise of the Tomb Raider or even Halo 5 and LA Noire, every game looks great on either display. This is a far cry from the PS4 Pro, wherein the game developer has to provision for it. Hopefully Sony decides to go the Xbox way with a future update. Until then, games on the Xbox One X have an advantage in terms of graphical fidelity.This Xbox one x is by far the most powerful console to date with 7 teraflops of computing power some of the newest chips blue ray and 4K functionality and more! What I‚Äôm most impressed with is the speed and quality of gameplay as well as COLLECTION OF GAMES!! The amount of games that support 4K for launch is unbelievable! Microsoft you really outdid yourself here! I highly recommend this console if you‚Äôre an Xbox fan you will highly enjoy this and if your PlayStation but want a faster console with this capability it won‚Äôt disappoint hope this helps!

I bought an Xbox one x last week and it‚Äôs my first Xbox ever.  I‚Äôve always been on PlayStation and I own the ps4 and ps4 pro.  Comparing the Xbox one to the ps4 is a tough one and overall and I think I still would pick PlayStation as a first pick in future consoles.  The reason why is because Sony just does it right.  While Xbox does have nifty features, such as backwards compatibility, cross play from pc to Xbox, etc.  The one major problem I noticed is that it seems Xbox has more technical flaws with it. I have never had any issues with the PlayStation, on hardware malfunction, etc.  The Xbox however I noticed it acts more like a pc.  I‚Äôm browsing through Microsoft store and there is lag scrolling through the games.  I joined an Xbox community on Facebook, and I‚Äôm always seeing someone asking for help with a technical issue.  I hope I don‚Äôt have any of those issues and time will tell.  The ui on the Xbox really needs a makeover.  It can be really annoying to navigate to get to where you want, as on the ps4, it‚Äôs not.  For example, destiny 2 expansions, it shows right up under the ps4 title, making it very accessible to buy.  On Xbox, I have to go to the game page, click destiny 2 with expansion, and then click on the expansion.  It‚Äôs pretty tedious.  One thing I almost forgot is hard drive swapping.  Ps4, its pretty simple and sony makes it really easy.  As for xbox, you pretty much have to take the whole thing I part.  You're better off buying an external hard drive.Game wise the, Xbox performs beautifully and I can see why people go with the system.  The ps4 pro and Xbox one x are pretty comparable when it comes to running games, and I noticed it really depends on the game and developer to make the 4k visual outstanding.  I‚Äôve read article where this game on ps4 pro looks better.  Then I see another game where it looks better on Xbox one x.Another nifty feature that I wish the ps4 would have is a game pass.  I like how some of the new Xbox games go straight to the pass and you can play before buying or just keep a subscription. Then also play that game on pc.  Which is pretty awesome.  The backwards compatibility is another great feature I wish ps4 would have and I wish Sony would have kept that trend.  While the ps4 has PS now, it‚Äôs not as great, since you have to rely on internet to stream the game.Overall, I‚Äôm still pretty satisfied  I got the Xbox and how it acts until the next consoles come out will determine if I keep getting both systems. I'm still giving it 5 stars just because of the nifty stuff it can do.

I don't understand all the hype that surrounded this newer console. I had an Xbox One for a year and a half and while it did lag, and games froze or crashed, it wasn't all that bad. I preferred it over the PS3 I had, so I didn't complain.Delayed buying this newer version mainly because of the price (which I feel is vastly outrageous), and since my games played well enough on my old one, I figured I'd wait a bit.Well, I finally broke down and bought it, and now I wish to hell I hadn't. It's worse than the old console; games freeze or crash about twice as much, and I can see no difference in graphics at all (though to be fair, that may be my TV's fault and not the unit, idk.)I would have sent it back, but I'd already promised my old console to someone, assuming this one would live up to all the great things people were saying and writing about the X.

The Xbox One X is the best console on the market right now, hands down. It's the only console where you can legitimately get native 4K graphics with HDR. The PS4 Pro usually produces a fake 4K using checkerboard and this is evident in the most recent release (as of writing this review) Red Dead Redemption 2. The PS4 Pro version, while a beautiful game, is obviously subpar when compared against the Xbox One X. The one thing the PS4Pro does have going for it though are games, and that is something you need to consider when buying this console.When you decide on buying a console, you are mainly looking for two things. 1) where are my friends going to be playing and 2) what exclusive games are on the console. Sony has Microsoft beat by a country mile with exclusives. You'll be able to play all third party games though (think Assassins Creed, Call of Duty, etc.) but games specific to Sony will only be on the PS4 system, and they are numerous. I have both consoles and while I always play third party games on my Xbox One X, I wouldn't want to miss some of the games on the PS4.So, with that out of the way, how is the console itself? It's amazing. Beautiful 4K gaming with HDR, a great online experience, and the console is whisper silent. You take for granted just how quiet a console is until you get a loud console like the PS4 Pro. It's one of the reasons I wanted to get an Xbox One X, playing games on the PS4 Pro was like playing them next a vacuum cleaner. Don't believe me? Youtube it...it's jarring.All in all, the console is amazing and I love it. If you want to experience all of the big games out there, the PS4 will probably be more your speed because you'll be missing out on some if this is your only console. But, if you already have a PS4 or have friends on the Xbox ecosystem, you're in for one heck of a console!

I bought the original Xbox One at launch in 2013. After 5 years, it was still going strong, but load times on certain games were long and I hated that my next gen console, while better than the 360, could barely handle 1080p at decent frame rates. It was disappointing but I made do as I‚Äôm strictly a casual, console player.I upgraded my TV to 4K HDR so I figured now was the time to look at the XOX. After reading reviews and waiting for a good deal, I got it at a reasonable price (much less than retail). I was a little afraid that I wouldn‚Äôt be able to notice the difference in picture quality and performance because some reviewers gave it bad marks.However, after doing a long evening of installs, I am very impressed with performance. For starters, load times were drastically reduced for several of the games I played. Destiny 2 had no frame rate drops during a 12 person public event, no loading pauses while exploring planets on the sparrow. Visually, everything did in fact look much sharper and smoother. Not just a little bit either, but an actual difference. I was pleasantly surprised.Opening some other games, I noticed a lot of the same. Noticeably better graphics and performance.I will say, if you plan to get this, you should do a review of your TV capabilities to get the most out of the console. I was irritated to learn that I can‚Äôt use all the features because my TV doesn‚Äôt support the right standards. This was frustrating as hell to be honest because I thought all 4K HDR should be supported on the device, but apparently my TV isn‚Äôt fancy enough for the console.All in all, I‚Äôd recommend it because it does work a LOT better than the original console in nearly every aspect. But definitely invest a little more for a top end TV to get the most out of it.

If you're looking for the best graphics games have to offer I must say the Xbox One X falls very short of the performance that most gaming PCs will achieve. With that said, for the price the Xbox One X is a bargain considering what it can do when a game is optimized well. The 4K output is crisp although the checkerboarding method used to achieve it leaves subtle artifacts just like on the PS4 Pro. Games will look good but, there is usually quite a bit of aliasing left. This means you will still get a slightly softer image overall when compared most games best settings in 4K. Not all games display in 4k and the games that do don't always stay in 4k. The fps in some games still does leave something to be desired and you will notice that some games will have occasional framerate and/or resolution drops at times. The PS4 Pro is not quite as powerful but, for most games there really isn't much difference in quality between it and the One X. Still, if you are looking to play the newest games in 4k this is the most powerful console to do it on and at low price compared to PC.

As a disclaimer, it's still (very, very) early on so things can change. I'll update this review if/when they do, but for now this is more of a 4-star product since it falls short in many areas.THE PRICE. You can grab a brand new Xbox One S with 3 games (and a built in UHD 4k drive) for 200 bucks. The XBox One X costs 2.5 times that at 500. For that you get the same 4K UHD drive, same controller, no games but a beefed up system. While the system is an upgrade over the PS4 Pro, that system is also a year older and came out 100-bucks less.Inside the box are a standard XBox One controller, 2 batteries (no rechargable pack included; this is optional), an HDMI cable and a power cable. I was disappointed that there is no stand for the console unless you buy the "Scorpio Edition" and that there is no mic/headphone in-box.CAPACITY: Another big issue is the capacity. Out of the box you get a 1TB Drive. Mine had about 780GB of actual usable space. While this might be fine for an Xbox One or PS4.. the 4K textures on these games are insane. Quantum Break, for instance, is 180GB. That's 1/4 of the capacity of the system and also means you'll need to download all 180GB of it.For something that has such large games (others are near 100GB each), it's insane to only have a 1TB drive. If you have to uninstall/re-install games, you'll need to re-download these. While you can buy external drives, these are another expense.4K UHD Player: A big selling point here since these players can cost quite a bit (I own the OPPO UDP-203 which is more than the Xbox One X); the downside is that the Xbox will not output DolbyVision HDR. With this being the superior form of HDR, Xbox One X Only allows for HDR10.AUDIO: Similarly to the Xbox One/Xbox One S, enabling Dolby Atmos for headphones is another 15-dollar purchase. The console does have audio output via HDMI and Optical audio which is nice.GAMES: The big thing here are the games. Play all your Xbox One games and also some backwards compatibility with the Xbox 360 and original Xbox. Nice!Xbox One games which are enhanced via patches are a free upgrade (also nice!)The Xbox One X is not an "Xbox Two", it's still an Xbox One but with some much beefed-up insides. There are no XboxOneX-only games, all games must be backwards compatible with the Xbox One  (from 2013). This is nice but also a disappointment as you're paying next-gen-console prices for current-gen games and hoping they're enhanced. Some games aren't but may run better.. others match the PS4 Pro in terms of upgrades.With so many consoles (the lower-spec Xbox One X, the PS4, last years' PS4 Pro and the most powerful Xbox One X (not to mention the switch)), the games will need to run on all consoles and will be designed for such. This may limit the games we see on the Xbox One X since they need to run well on the older consoles also. Will developers take the time to put out multiple versions of these games?VR: One big benefit of the PS4 Pro is the VR. The Pro enhanced the PSVR system and allows for better gameplay. This is a big selling point of the Pro, but Xbox currently does not have any type of VR system.So what does the X do? it  does 4K and does it great. I feel a bit let down by all of the issues above, but it is the most powerful console out there. I just wish I didn't have to spend so much on it and still have an incomplete system.I'm looking forward to what it has to offer (and bought the console knowing it will be a longer term 'investment' to allow keep playing these games in the best way possible) but the future remains to be seen.With the PS4 Pro already cheaper and a year old, will we be seeing a PS5 soon?Even the original Xbox One is 4 years old. I don't  know if Microsoft can keep this going for another 4-5 years on this hardware.

For $500 you get a Vega architecture GPU that's capable of pushing 4k games, UHD BluRay, a TB of storage and it's all packed in a sleek package. I do not currently own a 4k TV, will invest in a LG SJ8*** at some time, but honestly the upgraded horsepower is translated to 1080p with upgraded graphics. Coming from a midrange PC, I played GOW4 at medium presets and compared to the quality of the One X the PC fell short. So I know some have said don't bother unless you have a 4k television but that's far from the truth, seeing the performance at 1080p and how awesome it looks only shows that at 4k it can be even better.So to wrap it up I sold my PC to get a Xbox One X and I don't regret it in the least! You'd be hard pressed to build a PC to match what you get with the One X you'd easily spend double the cost of the One X.

For the record, I game on a Vega 56, i5-8600K @ 4.9GHz. I've owned a Nintendo Switch, 3DS, Xbox One, Xbox One S, PS4, PS4 Pro, PS3, Xbox 360, and the list goes on.But in terms of which console has won me over for pure value, it is the Xbox One X. Nothing on the market even comes close to what you are getting in this package. If buying into the newest trends have taught me something over the years, it's that not everything is completely worth your hard-earned money.So why buy an Xbox One X if I own a Vega 56? It's honestly quite simple. I absolutely hate playing on a Keyboard and Mouse. I can't stand it. I've done it for years, I tried to like it. But it isn't for me. And not every PC game has the greatest controller support, and some don't have any at all. Case in point: Path of Exile. Wonderful game. Controller support on PC? None. You have to play it on Xbox for that. There are many others, but this is a good example.Now the first Xbox One X I received on launch day was defective. Hard lock-ups, couldn't play more than 10 minutes without it restarting itself. However, the second one I got recently was absolutely perfect. No issues whatsoever. Keep in mind that if you experience issues don't hesitate to return it and get an exchange. Buy the Xbox One X at BestBuy if you'd like to streamline this. They will exchange without any questions asked.As it stands, if I could only own one console. It would be the Xbox One X. I'd recommend one to anyone. From hardcore computer gamer to casual. The visual fidelity and performance is bar-none the best you will ever get at this price point.

Just a note, didn't purchase on Amazon got it from the Microsoft Store Online so I could pay using PayPal.  Now for my review,Just plain Awesome!!! Now I am coming from a Original Xbox One, The footprint it takes up is shockingly small compared to my One. It is also super quiet! Also just to note I have it hooked up to a 43 inch Vizio LED 1080P TV (120hz)  and the difference in graphics and how smooth the games run is really amazing. I do wish it came with a bigger internal Hard drive but I already had a 4TB drive hooked up to my One which is now delegated to the bed room due to our bedroom tv is not smart so we can use it for Netflix and other streaming apps. I really question the 1 star reviews that are not Verified purchases. I really think it's people trying to bring down the overall score of the One X. This really is a quality machine if you can afford it. I have played Call of Duty World War 2 and Wolfenstein 2 and Forza 7 all look and play amazing. Also tried out Quantum Break and boy does that run so much smoother!!!  Very Happy with my Purchase!!! If anything changes I will update but I have had it running 24 hours straight and all is well.  Oh did have a little hiccup with the initial update I had to "hit re-try" once, also installing games take a while but that is the norm with all the new consoles so people giving it once star for that is just plane ridiculous!

Honestly I had high hopes for this system, despite reading some of the negative reviews I figured people tend to exaggerate. Unfortunately 5 days after I got my Xbox One X I was in the middle of playing a game and the system shut off on me. I tried to power it on again and it wouldn't turn on, after speaking to a Micrsoft rep he told me he would send me another power cord cause that's what the problem sounded like. So I tried that and still wouldn't turn on. I finally got fed up and sent it back for a refund and got another Xbox One S. Needless to say I won't be getting another one X. I'm so sick of Microsoft's products always failing on me I might just convert to Sony!!!

MICROSOFT'S premium CONSOLE IS NOW DISCONTINUED, BUT THE CURRENT PRICE ON THE LAST ONES AVAILABLE IS POSITIVELY INCREDIBLE. While the Console is fantastic, I have to bring up a few blatant negatives yet to be resolved- but from the XBOX domain apart from this amazing unit. Firstly; XBOX continues to cater to slobs who love shooters, and I have yet to finish a single RPG- my favorite type of game- including past backward-compatible titles. Second- the dreadful onslaught of pathetic EA sports games. Third- action-games often allocated to the RPG section of titles. Fourth- abysmal Web interface that downloads at 1/3 the speed of my PS4. But I have some hope- since Kemco has been providing turn-based old-fashioned and adorable RPG'S at the manageable price of $14.99 a title. The games are in the vein of "As-Divine" and are simply FUN to play! In addition, the last breed of 360 titles like "Blue Dragon" and "Lost Odyssey" are always going to be among my fave X-Box offerings. However- a dark spot on X-Box is the Final Fantasy 15 money-grabbing beast of horrific proportions that is so awful it may very well be the end of the series. Before I smash it and bury it, however; I will get it for my PS4 PRO. All in all this model is on it's way OUT- but this price for the "king" of consoles simply cannot be ignored. Sadly- the games do not follow the same pattern.

Microsoft delivered on their promise. This bad boy is much more powerful than even the PS4 pro. Games look great in 4k HDR. The Xbox does true 4k with no need to checkerboard in most games. Forza 7 plays in 2160p60 HDR which is incredibly impressive for a 500 dollar console. If you want the best experience for a multiplatform game, the X is for you.I own a PS4 Pro as well, which now feels obsolete outside exclusives. You get your money's worth with the X since the 4k blu ray player is great as well.

At this price we should all have high expectations, and overall this product is full of disappointing design flaws, errors, and ugly ads/content that can not be disabled.If you‚Äôre looking for an elegant product you can be proud to display on your living room display look elsewhere. The home screen is a disaster, by default not family-friendly. You can disable the gross cartoon T&A by setting the age filter (not very intuitive), but you can never disable all ads or remove the streaming channels or social network stuff that may be useless to you.The media remote that you have to purchase separately is a piece of junk. No Bluetooth, all black so it‚Äôs hard to find in a dark room, the battery cover pops off easily, and the volume controls over IR blaster only increment your A/V equipment one click at a time so you have to repeatedly press volume keys and can not hold them down. Soooo frustratingly stupid. Then there are bugs: The Console will randomly not sign in or connect to wi-fi requiring a manual restart and lots of waiting. Discs randomly will not play when inserted. Apps randomly get signed out (like plex), more waiting and frustration.These are unacceptable issues at this price point. I have an Apple TV 4K and it has none of this issues. Yes some 4K HDR games are only available on Xbox, but if you are expecting a quality user experience and a well-functioning media player, you will be very disappointed.
Xbox itself appeared to be in good shape. However, the "right stick" and "right bumper" are severely damaged and do not work at all. This was not listed in the description of the used product.

Pre ordered this bad boy at the beginning of Sept.I was contemplating on getting the PS4 Pro for the upgraded VR visuals over my OG PS4 and new released games coming in 2018, but I decided not to bc I wanted to take full advantage of my 4k TV that I spent close to 2 grand on.Pros:-Gameplay visuals are absolutely stunning. AC: Orgins, The Witcher 3, COD WWII, and Halo 5 are the games that I've tried with true 4K. They look astounding and its jaw dropping. FIFA, NHL, and Madden all look good too, but I mainly play RPGs and shooters.-The size is so small and the console runs super quiet-Loading times in offline RPGs like the Witcher are drastically reduced.-Dashboard is smoother than my Day One XB1-No more power brick-4K blu-raymany more to go overCons:-Only 1TB... Halo is almost 100GB.. Buy an external hard drive if you intend on having close to a dozen games at once on this console-Still need a dang Kinect adapter that Microsoft recently discontinued...-Lack of exclusives on release, and it doesn't look like there will be too strong of a 2018 for Xbox either.... Sea of Thieves and State of Decay 2? Please.... PS4 is absolutely embarrassing Xbox in this regard.All in all, this thing is a BEAST. Other than exclusives, this is the best console on the planet. Looks like nothing will touch this until 2019-2020.

So, I recently purchased an Xbox One X on launch day in November of last year and I wanted to share my thoughts on it. I came from an Xbox 360 and this guy is sooooooo much quieter. Mine can get pretty hot because it doesn't have as much ventilation around it but it never slows down because of that(It's gotten up to 110 degrees. I made sure it had ventilation too.) Gameplay is very smooth on it. I will not say it never has a hiccup because that's not true, but if it does it recovers within milliseconds. I love the layout of everything in the menu on the One X. Everything is relatively easy to find and navigate. Design wise, it's pretty basic with my only complaint being I wish they had another port for another wired controller like the original Xbox One. I'm pleased with the amount of games coming out that are "One X Enhanced" and that take advantage of it's power. I also love it coming with 1 TB of memory storage because you burn through that memory very quick with updates and downloading games on it. I have watched Blu-ray movies on it and it performs flawlessly too. Overall, I think this is an outstanding system that is great if you have a 4K TV. I can't speak for the PS4 Pro, but I personally love my One X and don't regret paying $500. It is worth every cent to me.

Last Christmas, my parents bought my brothers and I a new console; the Xbox One X. Prior to this, I had been playing on an Xbox One S but the Xbox One X blew it out of the ballpark. Although it has a relatively high price tag, its 4k graphics and a wide variety of games/apps make up for the price.  The Xbox One X includes 4k graphics, which means there are 4 times the pixels as standard full HD. The higher resolution is a huge plus to buying this console. The Xbox One X GPU is a high-end graphics card by AMD. Due to these specs, the Xbox One X can run games at a higher frame rate than its competitor, the PS4 Pro. The increased framerate stands out in demanding games such as Forza Horizon and Halo 5.  The Xbox One X also includes a wide variety of games and apps to download. I would recommend purchasing an external hard drive for storage, for the games do take up a large amount of storage. Xbox has a wide variety of games and apps to choose from, ranging from MMO‚Äôs to RPG‚Äôs. It also has built-in 4k Blu ray, which the PS4 Pro does not currently have.  One thing that you might need to overcome is the price. Starting at around 499 dollars (at its release), it isn‚Äôt cheap. I have played many hours of all kinds of games and apps, and all this time has proven to me that all the cool and unique features on the Xbox One X make it worth every dollar. When your spending all this money, you deserve only the best, you really notice that with its fast loading speeds, faster than any other console.  Overall, the Xbox One X is outstanding for someone trying to take their gaming experience to a new level. The only thing that lowers my rating would be the high price that is hard to overcome. Thanks to massive updates, high frame rates, and fast loading speeds, the system will always be fresh. There are loads of games to play and accessories to upgrade your gaming experience.

I purchased my Xbox One X last spring from a different retailer.  When it works, it's great.  However the other 80% of the time, it's been a huge headache.Things to keep in mind before purchasing:1. You must plug this console directly into an outlet (NOT a powerstrip).  Sure, many people don't do this, or even know about this.  However after MULTIPLE months of NUMEROUS calls to Microsoft, spending COUNTLESS hours on hold and on the phone with various "experts" in multiple countries, one thing they always mention is the fact that NOT plugging it directly into an outlet will cause the XBOX ONE X to run at 80% capacity.  That's right: If you have your XBOX ONE X plugged into a power strip, you're cheating yourself out of 20% of its power.  This information is readily available on all XBOX ONE X literature.2. This unit's "Wi-Fi" is either a running joke, or non-existent.  Buy an ethernet cable and hook your Xbox One X directly to your router.  The XBOX One X is terrible finding and staying connected to networks.  After a while, I got tired of doing a "factory reset" every day, just to access wireless functions (yes, that's the only way Microsoft employees could solve the problem).  My internet service is phenomenal and consistently strong/fast.  NONE of my other devices have even a small problem with my network.  My Switch, PS4, Xbox 360, and smart TV all work just fine. It's the Xbox One X that is flawed.In conclusion, only buy this console if you plan on plugging directly into an outlet, and you're able to connect it to the internet via an ethernet cable.  Otherwise, you're potentially setting yourself up for prolonged frustration.  I say "potentially" because I'm sure there are batches(?) of consoles out there that don't have these defects.  I'm sure there are plenty of people who own this console and it works just fine plugged into a powerstrip and it stays connected to the internet.  HOWEVER, there are MANY people out there with units like mine (google Xbox One X can't stay connected).I love this console when it works, however I'm not happy for having paid $500 for a faulty product which has caused so much frustration  Thankfully, it works fine for me now, but only because I use a ethernet cable.  I should also point out that Microsoft's customer service has been gracious enough to provide 6 months of Xbox Live for all the trouble.
They put a label on the box saying EXACTLY what was inside. This was a gift for my boyfriend, who brought the package inside.

Just a quick heads up to anyone buying this device. So far, I love it. Like my PS4 Pro, games look much much better. Games seem to load faster too. I just hope MS takes advantage of the power by bringing some great exclusives like Sony has been doing. I was really excited for this new console, but I've had several issues that have yet to be fixed by either updates or support. The first being the HDMI port to the TV seems to be faulty. At random, the output will flash or disconnect entirely. This is not a cabling or TV issue, as I've swapped new cables and bought a new TV since my Xbox purchase. Additionally, some of my games have experienced major bugs since the first One X updates came through, the worst being Forza 3 Horizons. When I launch the game, certain menus take an extremely long time to load, or never launch properly at all. When I attempt to join races, the game crashes.
